comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Definitely the corner of O'Connell Street and Bachelor's Walk, with Westmoreland Street in the distance, over the bridge. Peterson's Pipes are still around.

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: ... and the base of the clock is still there on Hickey's Pharmacy!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I agree that this is in O'Connell Street just past the junction with Bachelors Walk!  These crowd scenes are excellent for looking at dress, uniforms, conditions and the changes that have taken place in the meantime.  The majority of the police on display here are DMP(G) with the bobby helmets with the exception of the Inspector/Officer on the left with either a sabre or walking stick.  The senior ranks of the Garda retained these sticks as part of the uniform right up to the Conroy Commission in the late '60's.  Kapp and Petersons were the shop on the corner and a source of great pipes and fine tobacco in the days when smoking was healthy and beneficial to all an sundry!

comment.author: 75671375@N05
comment._content: Definitely O'Connell St.; you have uploaded several other photos that show the Kapp & Peterson building on that corner by the bridge, including one from the Eucharistic Congress in 1932.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Yep, Kapp & Peterson have just moved southside to the bottom of Grafton Street. Thanks for the Tram Stop note, Niall! I wasn't at all sure of what it was...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] Civility indeed! Can't work out what that's about...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] Well spotted! And while I was checking out the base of the clock in the original, noticed a man standing in the window... Great how often window "looker outers" (technical term) were captured in old photos, and random dogs too - though couldn't find any creatures of a canine persuasion in this one.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75671375@N05] Thanks for the reminder! That is a great shot of this corner from south of the Liffey...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] What does the G stand for in DMP (G)?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: NLI the DMPmerged with the Civic Guard in 1925 and became the Garda Síochána from then on.Many of the former DMP stayed on and from 1925 were known as the Dublin Metropolitan Guards or DMG.  They retained the DMP uniform and Dublin people to this day call them policemen rather than Garda as us culchies do!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Ah, DMG then! And why Guard and The Guards is used rather than Garda...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 26640250@N02
comment._content: It does seem the only way of getting this shot was from the upstairs of a tram, notice the reflection of the rounded window frame on the left as well as some glass reflections in the middle of the frame.

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.author: 62379908@N00
comment._content: Transportation in those days included vehicles such as motor cars and horse drawn carriages.  I also see trolley tracks, and there was likely a railway station nearby.  The 21st century is not very far ahead in the transportation department, especially in America where the choices are often drive or walk.
